He is of [[Senegal]]ese origin.
==Club career== ===Cannes=== Bellion started his career at [[AS Cannes|Cannes]] at the age of 14, and earned a move to English side [[Sunderland A.F.C.|Sunderland]] in the summer of 2001. In his youth he was a talented athlete, competing in the 2001 National Indoor Youth Championships he won the 60 metres.<ref>http://www.francefootball.fr/FF/breves2007/20070807_141337Dev.html</ref>
===Sunderland=== He made his [[Sunderland A.F.C.|Sunderland]] senior debut at [[Fulham F.C.|Fulham]] in August 2001, coming on as a substitute. The Frenchman's first senior goal was against [[Aston Villa F.C.|Aston Villa]] at the [[Stadium of Light]] which gave [[City of Sunderland|Sunderland]] a 1â0 win in September 2002.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_prem/2272638.stm|title=Sunderland edge to victory|publisher=[[BBC]]|date=28 September 2002 |accessdate=27 August 2009}}</ref> Following the goal, Bellion found himself a first team regular at Sunderland, although was unable to save them from [[Promotion and relegation|relegation]] with the third-lowest [[Premier League]] points tally ever. Towards the end of the season, Bellion attracted interest from [[Manchester United F.C.|Manchester United]], and angered many fans by going [[desertion|AWOL]] to France at a time when the Black Cats needed him most. Upon returning, Bellion claimed he had been visiting his sick grandmother, and made himself temporarily unavailable for selection, claiming he was "mentally unfit" to be playing in a relegation battle. At the time, speculation was rife that Bellion had been "tapped up" by United, although Manchester United and Bellion's [[Sports agent|agent]] firmly denied this. Despite this, Bellion agreed a move to the "Red Devils" after his contract expired in June 2003, although the transfer was not without controversy. As Bellion was under the age of 23, Sunderland were eligible for compensation, and a fee of Â£2 million, rising to Â£3 million depending on appearances, was agreed out of court. The fee was agreed on the basis that Sunderland chairman [[Bob Murray (businessman)|Bob Murray]] signed a "confidentiality agreement" and did not launch a complaint against Manchester United over the alleged "tapping up" of Bellion, after former [[Arsenal F.C.|Arsenal]] vice-chairman [[David Dein]] claimed Bellion had been offered to Arsenal by his agent illegally,{{Citation needed|date=May 2007}} and that United had been paying for Bellion's mobile phone bills whilst still at Sunderland.{{Citation needed|date=April 2009}}
===Manchester United=== Bellion moved to [[Old Trafford]] in August 2003 and scored on his debut against [[Celtic F.C.|Celtic]] on the club's pre-season American tour. His first competitive goal came at [[Leeds United A.F.C.|Leeds United]] in the [[Football League Cup|League Cup]],<ref>{{cite web |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/league_cup/3204813.stm |title=Leeds 2â3 Man Utd |publisher=[[BBC Sport]] |date=28 October 2003 |accessdate=16 September 2009}}</ref> and the striker scored two goals in the [[2003â04 in English football|2003â04]] season â against [[Everton F.C.|Everton]]<ref>{{cite web |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_prem/3316125.stm |title=Man Utd 3â2 Everton |publisher=[[BBC]] |date=26 December 2003 |accessdate=16 September 2009}}</ref> and [[Tottenham Hotspur F.C.|Tottenham Hotspur]],<ref>{{cite web |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_prem/3507784.stm |title=Man Utd 3â0 Tottenham |publisher=[[BBC Sport]] |date=20 March 2004 |accessdate=16 September 2009}}</ref> both at Old Trafford.
Despite a smattering of early-season goals against Norwich City<ref>{{cite web |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_prem/3564566.stm |title=Man Utd 2â1 Norwich |publisher=[[BBC Sport]] |date=21 August 2004 |accessdate=16 September 2009}}</ref> and Bolton Wanderers,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_prem/3599088.stm |title=Bolton 2â2 Man Utd |publisher=[[BBC Sport]] |date=11 September 2004 |accessdate=16 September 2009}}</ref> the [[2004â05 in English football|2004â05]] campaign proved equally frustrating for Bellion as he found himself increasingly frozen out of the first team picture. A fruitful spell in the Reserves followed, but Bellion's season was curtailed in early May when he suffered a fractured fibula against Charlton Reserves. Bellion spent time on loan at [[West Ham United F.C.|West Ham United]] at the beginning of the [[2005â06 in English football|2005â06]] season, returning to [[Sunderland A.F.C.|Sunderland]] for the first time as an unused substitute for the Hammers in October 2005, where he was booed whilst warming up. He scored on his debut, a [[Football League Cup|League Cup]] win over [[Sheffield Wednesday F.C.|Sheffield Wednesday]] on 20 September 2005,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/league_cup/4258504.stm |title=Sheff Wed 2â4 West Ham |publisher=[[BBC]] |date=20 September 2005 |accessdate=27 August 2009}}</ref> and went on to make ten appearances for the club, mostly as [[Substitute (association football)|substitute]].
===Nice=== He returned to France on 9 January 2006, joining Nice, a loan until the end of the season that was made a permanent move in June 2006.
===Bordeaux=== Bellion joined [[FC Girondins de Bordeaux|Bordeaux]] on 15 July 2007, signing a four-year deal. He marked his first match by scoring the only goal in Bordeaux's 1â0 win over [[RC Lens|Lens]].
===Nice=== In December 2010, Bellion returned to [[OGC Nice|Nice]] on loan until the end of the season.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.ogcnice.com/actualite/news.php?clef=6697 |title=Accord pour le prÃªt de Bellion }}</ref>
